channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Another Mass Grave Dug by ISIS in Iraq, and a Ghastly Ritual Renewed
item.media:description: A tied and decomposed body at a mass grave found at a trash dump on the outskirts of Hamam al-Alil, Iraq.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The Islamic State has been resorting to a horrific practice that dates back to Saddam Hussein and his regime’s industrial-scale killings.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Cyberattacks Strike Saudi Arabia, Harming Aviation Agency
item.description: A version of Shamoon, the virus that hit Middle Eastern energy companies in 2012, was used in mid-November to attack government agencies.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Mahmoud Abbas Proposes Palestinian Unity Government With Hamas
item.media:description: Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, center, was greeted by fellow Fatah members on the second day of the Fatah party conference, in Ramallah, the West Bank, on Wednesday.
item.description: Addressing a conference of his Fatah party, Mr. Abbas sought to push forward long-stalled efforts to reconcile the two major competing Palestinian factions.
item.dc:creator: RAMI NAZZAL and PETER BAKER

item.title: Colombia’s Congress Approves Peace Accord With FARC
item.media:description: Colombia’s House of Representatives on Wednesday. The Senate and the House, controlled by President Juan Manuel Santos’s governing coalition, voted unanimously for a peace agreement.
item.description: The vote was most likely the final hurdle in ratifying the troubled agreement whose earlier version had been rejected in a referendum this fall.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Doomed Jet Carrying Brazilian Team Reportedly Ran Out of Fuel
item.media:description: Rescue workers on Tuesday combed through the wreckage of a jet carrying 77 people that crashed near Medellín, Colombia.
item.description: The pilot pleaded to make an immediate landing because of the situation, according to a recording leaked to Colombian news organizations.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and EWAN MacKENNA

item.title: As a Distracted Brazil Mourns, Lawmakers Gut a Corruption Bill
item.description: With Brazilians stunned by the crash of a plane carrying a soccer team, lawmakers made dead-of-night changes to a bill meant to keep officials honest.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Great Barrier Reef Threatened by Climate Change, Chemicals and Sediment
item.media:description: A scientist assessing coral mortality on a section of the Great Barrier Reef in an undated photograph. A new report from the Australian government paints a grim picture of the scale of protecting the 1,400-mile-long reef.
item.media:credit: Andreas Dietzel/ARC Center of Excellence for Coral Reef Studies
item.description: An Australian government report to Unesco says the risks are well-managed, but it also paints a grim picture of the scale of protecting the area.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: U.N. Stiffens Sanctions on North Korea, Trying to Slow Its Nuclear March
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, in an undated photograph issued by his government’s Korean Central News Agency on Nov. 11.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The key to enforcing the Security Council’s new penalties on coal exports remains in the hands of China, North Korea’s principal coal customer.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: 3 Chinese Rights Activists Vanish, Apparently in State Crackdown
item.media:description: Jiang Tianyong in 2012.
item.description: The three men vanished within days of one another in different provinces, rights groups said, and only one has been charged by the police.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: One Family. Six Decades. Myriad Views of Fidel Castro’s Revolution.
item.media:description: Fidel Castro after arriving in Havana on Jan. 8, 1959. Mr. Castro’s revolution was welcomed by Cubans like Juan Montes Torre, a poor laborer at the time. “It was an emotional shock,” Mr. Montes recalled. “These bearded men, poorly dressed — they won! And on behalf of the lower classes!”
item.description: The clash of emotions common in Cuban families is reflected in a grandfather’s loyalty to Mr. Castro and a granddaughter’s glum view of conditions in her country.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Donald Trump’s Threat to Close Door Reopens Old Wounds in Cuba
item.media:description: President Obama met with the Cuban president, Raúl Castro, in Havana in March.
item.description: In a post on Twitter, he said he would “terminate” the pact President Obama made if Cuba is unwilling to make “a better deal for the Cuban people.”
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE, AZAM AHMED and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Subdued Cuba Prepares Memorial for Castro
item.description: A two-day memorial and a period of “Duelo Nacional,” or national mourning, will offer Cubans a chance to pay their respects to the longtime leader.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Little Fidel in All of Us
item.media:description: People in Miami reacting to the news of the death of Fidel Castro.
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.description: Who would any of us be if he hadn’t rearranged our destinies and caused this rupture in our lives?
item.dc:creator: ACHY OBEJAS

item.title: Fidel Castro, Cuban Revolutionary Who Defied U.S., Dies at 90
item.media:description: Fidel Castro was seen as a ruthless despot by some and hailed as a revolutionary hero by others.
item.description: Mr. Castro brought the Cold War to the Western Hemisphere, bedeviled 11 American presidents and briefly pushed the world to the brink of nuclear war.
item.dc:creator: ANTHONY DePALMA

item.title: Lufthansa Joins Germany’s List of Companies in Distress
item.media:description: Lufthansa pilots on strike at Frankfurt Airport on Wednesday.
item.description: A strike by pilots at the airline has caused travel problems in Europe and threatened to damage Germany’s longstanding cooperation between management and labor.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Prince Harry Announces a Scholarship to Serve the Royal Family
item.media:description: Prince Harry inspected the guard of honor after arriving in Bridgetown to commemorate the 50th independence anniversary of Barbados on Tuesday.
item.description: Recipients of the scholarship will spend time in Buckingham Palace, but don’t get the wrong idea: They will cook, cater and otherwise serve the British royals.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Charlie Hebdo, a Lightning Rod in France, Hits German Newsstands
item.media:description: The first issue of the German edition of Charlie Hebdo in Berlin on Thursday.
item.description: The satirical newspaper, the target of an attack in 2015 that killed top editors and cartoonists, has started a German edition that features Angela Merkel on its first cover.
item.dc:creator: CHARLY WILDER

item.title: Mont Péko Journal: Ousting Farmers to Save Forest, Ivory Coast Sets Off a New Crisis
item.media:description: Workers filling sacks with cocoa beans at an agricultural cooperative in Guiglo, Ivory Coast.
item.description: Squatters using protected land to grow cocoa have helped strip the country of four-fifths of its woodlands. Now evicted, many of them are struggling to survive.
item.dc:creator: SEAN LYNGAAS

item.title: Gambia’s Leader Vowed to Rule for a Billion Years. A Vote Will Test That.
item.media:description: President Yahya Jammeh’s final rally in Banjul, Gambia, on Tuesday, ahead of the presidential election.
item.description: Enthusiasm for President Yahya Jammeh’s rival has put into question the outcome of the country’s election and prompted fears of instability and violence.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: What in the World: On an Island Named for Ice, the Poets Are Just Getting Warmed Up
item.media:description: Poetician (2016), by Birgitta Jónsdóttir | DOWNLOAD
item.media:credit: Design and Illustration by Helga Dögg
item.description: In Iceland, people of all ages and every walk of life compose and publish verse. Cold, damp weather and long winter nights may be among the reasons.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Buzz Aldrin Is Evacuated From the South Pole After Falling Ill
item.media:description: Buzz Aldrin in Australia in November.
item.description: The former astronaut and second man to walk on the moon was flown to New Zealand after he arrived for a private tour.
item.dc:creator: ERIN McCANN

item.title: Sinosphere: Whistle-Blowing AIDS Doctor Reflects on Roots of Epidemic in China
item.media:description: Dr. Gao Yaojie, who helped expose H.I.V.-tainted blood sales in Henan Province, in her apartment in New York last month.
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.description: Dr. Gao Yaojie, who has tied the epidemic to an unsanitary network of blood sales, discussed what she considers the still-untold truth about AIDS in China.
item.dc:creator: LUO SILING

item.title: Counterterrorism Law to Let Australia Detain Convicts After Their Sentences
item.media:description: George Brandis, left, the attorney general of Australia, and Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull at Parliament House in Canberra this week.
item.media:credit: Lukas Coch/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.description: The law allows extensions of up to three years for convicts who are judged to be a continuing threat, with no limit on the number of renewals.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: South Korean Arrested After Fire at Birthplace of President’s Father
item.media:description: The burned birthplace of the military dictator Park Chung-hee, the father of President Park Geun-hye, in Gumi, South Korea, on Thursday.
item.description: The fire destroyed part of a memorial to Park Chung-hee, the assassinated dictator and father of South Korea’s embattled president, Park Geun-hye.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Police Confiscate Passports in Parts of Xinjiang, in Western China
item.media:description: Uighurs last year in Kashgar, in the far western Chinese region of Xinjiang. The government, dominated by the Han ethnic group, has tightened control in areas with Uighurs, who are mostly Sunni Muslims.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Residents and online notices reveal no obvious pattern to the restrictions in the region, where ethnic Uighurs have chafed under tightening government control.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Guggenheim Helsinki Museum Plans Are Rejected
item.media:description: A rendering of the design for the new Guggenheim Helsinki. Plans for the museum have been voted down.
item.description: Lawmakers in the Finnish city voted down a proposal to pay for a $138 million museum with a mix of private and public money.
item.dc:creator: NINA SIEGAL

item.title: E.U. Plans Big Increase in Military Spending
item.description: The plan comes at a time when the bloc is seeking to rely less on the security guarantees of the United States.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Tunisia Seeks Foreign Investment to Cement Democratic Gains
item.media:description: Prime Minister Youssef Chahed of Tunisia at Parliament in Tunis this month. Only three months into the job, he faces the urgent task of rescuing the economy.
item.description: The country where the Arab Spring began five years ago is trying to bolster its economy, especially in the less developed interior, as it combats terrorism.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Jovenel Moïse Is Elected President of Haiti After Delays and Disasters
item.media:description: A billboard of Jovenel Moïse in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, this month. He was former President Michel Martelly’s handpicked successor.
item.description: Mr. Moïse, a banana exporter, received 55 percent of the vote in a field of 27 candidates, but three of his opponents are vowing to contest the results.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Thailand’s Civil Servants Urged to Take a Break to Break a Sweat
item.description: The ruling military junta has begun a voluntary program calling for government employees to exercise once a week during working hours.
item.dc:creator: POYPITI AMATATHAM and MIKE IVES

item.title: Britain’s New £5 Note, Stronger and Safer, Isn’t Suitable for Vegetarians
item.media:description: The new 5-pound note was unveiled in June and was said to be made out of polymer that would allow it to last more than twice as long as its cotton-paper predecessor.
item.description: The Bank of England has confirmed that tallow, a hard, fatty substance usually made from rendered beef or mutton suet, was used in the base of the new bills.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH OLIVENNES

item.title: Norcia Journal: Italian Monastery Seeks Salvation in Beer After Devastating Quake
item.media:description: Father Nivakoff, who is from Connecticut, in the historical center of Norcia. The beer brewery that he and other monks operate was mostly spared.
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.description: Their basilica in ruins, monks from America believe their small brewing operation can help an entire town to recover from Italy’s worst earthquake since 1980.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Indian Cinemas Must Play the National Anthem, Supreme Court Rules
item.media:description: A movie theater in Mumbai, India. Decades ago, Indian movie theaters routinely played the national anthem at the end of a movie, but the practice was discontinued.
item.description: The anthem, before every screening, is to be accompanied by images of the Indian flag, and the audience must stand, the ruling mandates.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Let Women Drive, a Prince in Saudi Arabia Urges
item.media:description: Prince Alwaleed bin Talal in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, in 2015. In a four-page letter posted on his personal website, the prince argued that “it is high time that Saudi women started driving their cars.”
item.description: “Beyond being a rights issue, it is also an economic, developmental and social one,” Alwaleed bin Talal wrote in a four-page letter posted on his personal website.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Bid to Impeach South Korean Leader Stalls as Lawmakers Debate Her Offer to Quit
item.media:description: Sim Sang-jung, head of the opposition Justice Party, mocked the president’s willingness to resign. “Her offer is like that of a student who faces expulsion for breaking school regulations but demands an early graduation,” she said on Twitter.
item.description: President Park Geun-hye’s offer to step down, without specifying a date, swayed some lawmakers, who said they were willing to accept an April departure.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: C.I.A. Chief Warns Donald Trump Against Tearing Up Iran Nuclear Deal
item.media:description: The C.I.A. director, John O. Brennan, in Washington in June. In an interview with the BBC, Mr. Brennan warned that the incoming administration needed to be skeptical about Russian promises.
item.description: John Brennan told the BBC that canceling the accord would be “the height of folly” and could lead to a nuclear arms race in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Sinosphere: Michael Flynn, a Top Trump Adviser, Ties China and North Korea to Jihadists
item.media:description: Retired Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn, the choice of President-elect Donald J. Trump for national security adviser, speaking at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland in July.
item.description: By appointing General Flynn, President-elect Donald J. Trump has signaled that he intends to prioritize policy on the Middle East and Islamist militants.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Taking a Selfie in Berlin, With a 3-Ton Camera
item.media:description: Susanna Kraus, left, the impresario and artist behind the Imago camera, unveiling a portrait of Christy Woody, right, in her Berlin studio. The photographs are taken straight onto reversal photo paper, not negative film.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Using complex and proprietary optics, the Imago camera creates life-size portraits directly on photo paper. A second Imago is in the works for Beijing.
item.dc:creator: GERRIT WIESMANN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Freedom Party’s Second Chance in Austria
item.media:description: Norbert Hofer.
item.description: The presidential election represents a renewed opportunity for the populist far right to extend its march across the electoral map of Europe.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MISIK

item.title: What’s at Stake: A World of Trouble for Donald Trump
item.description: Mr. Trump, who has offered only a jumble of contradictory ideas, will have a hard time dealing with urgent challenges abroad.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: What Trump Misses About Cuba
item.media:description: A parade for Fidel Castro in Havana, Cuba, in 1959, celebrated the fall of Fulgencio Batista.
item.description: Threats and self-dealing don’t get a negotiator very far in Havana.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM M. LEOGRANDE

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
